Just to confirm, this is not the intended end state of the container runner main, simply a step to rewind the hack we did before, right? SAMZA-1168 talks about launching StreamProcessor in container. In the end state, we want a proper implementation of application runner to launch the StreamProcessor in the container process, with start(); and waitForFinish(). Could you open a JIRA to track the end state of the container refactor effort?

Otherwise, lgtm. Thanks!
@lhaiesp : Sure, if you think it's substantial, we can certainly do it later. But, would be nice to do it before the next release. If you don't have cycles to pick it up, I will work on it :-)

Hey @pdu-mn1 : 

I'm +1 to this PR. On a related note @prateekm proposed that we consider if we need both configs (I'm +1 to his idea) I'm summarizing his proposal.  

max.pending.requests: it seems like we might be able to default it to "task.max.concurrency" or at-least derive from it since tables scoped within a task.

async.callback.pool.size: the current usage of the thread-pool appears to be just doing timer/metric updates. Since, we return a `CompletableFuture`, the user of the class can run callbacks by passing in in their own executors to `CompletableFuture#runAsync`.

This is unrelated to this PR per-say but would be good to consider regardless, before we release it in 1.0

Thanks for reviewing! 

Regarding the suggestion: 

- The checkin of the initial async API impl does not have max.pending.requests at all. We already rely on task.max.concurrency for traffic control.

- async.callback.pool.size does not only process metrics it also processes task callbacks which is the main reason we provided the option for job to specify the thread pool. By default, we don't use any thread pool for these, so it is opt-in feature.

Does this make sense? @prateekm @vjagadish1989

@pdu-mn1 re async.callback.pool.size, we're returning users a Future, and they can already provide a custom executor when chaining operations on a future. From a user's perspective, this seems more straightforward and natural than trying to supply a configuration to us.

In other words, if users understand why and how they should configure this pool size, wouldn't it be simpler for them to just provide an executor for their thenAsync etc operations instead?

I can think of two benefits of the current approach:

- it frees users from creating an executor and do runAsync with the executor for them, whereas they can simply supply a callback to us with the current approach with one line of config code. So this
is still a convenient feature for simple jobs. 

- With such config, the user is prompted to consider the implication of their callback methods supplied to us.

Neither reason is a blocker so I'm open to removing the config as well both you guys think otherwise. 

@prateekm @vjagadish1989

@pdu-mn1 My argument is the opposite of yours: 

If users understand when and why they should be executing callbacks on separate threads, it's simpler for them to use the standard CompletableFuture APIs to do this instead of an obscure Samza configuration. In fact, since we can't prevent them from using the Future APIs, and since they might not know the configuration exists, they're likely to use the Future APIs anyway.

If users don't understand the need for a separate callback executor, and we want to take the responsibility for telling them, configuration reference would be the wrong place to do so - we should document this in the API javadocs (i.e., close to when the need to understand this) instead. 

Another way to think about this: Even if we assume users always read all configurations, to make the configuration useful you'd have to describe when to use it and what to set it to. Wouldn't it be simpler to just do this in the method Javadocs and tell them to use separate executors?
@prateekm Very fair. I will add documentation for the expectations/semantics of the callback, along with removing the config.

During the re-balancing phase, stream processors in the group have to stop the `SamzaContainer` within the shutdown-timeout(task.shutdown.ms) and join the barrier.

If the samza container did not stop within this configured timeout, then the stream processor is killed.

In the failed integration tests, `task.shutdown.ms` is set to 2 seconds. In some scenarios, when the container shutdown took more than 2 seconds, thereby killing the  stream processor.

Since the integration test expects the stream processor to be alive, the assertion fails. 

The change here is to increase the coordination timeouts. In longer run, if we want faster dev builds we can extract these integration tests out in a seperate module and run them nightly. 

Verified the above changes by triggering the build for finite number of times in travis.

@cameronlee314 Just looking at the names in the description, I'd prefer to not use `key` in the names since it's an overloaded term. How about something along these lines:

1. TimerRegistry -> Scheduler; register -> schedule
2. TimerFunction -> ScheduledFunction; registerTimer -> schedule, onTimer -> onCallback
3. TimerCallback -> ScheduledCallback onTimer -> onCallback
4. TaskContext: registerTimer -> scheduleCallback, deleteTimer -> deleteScheduledCallback

This way we're only introducing 2 new terms - schedule and callback, and both are fairly familiar concepts.
@shanthoosh can you please take a look?

Thanks for the suggestion @prateekm. I wasn't too fond of KeyScheduler either. The reason I did use that name was that when we consolidate TaskContext.scheduleCallback and TaskContext.deleteScheduledCallback into a _TaskContext.something_, I was thinking of using "Scheduler" for that. Now, I'm thinking that I could use something like SchedulerCallbackRegistry for that TaskContext case.

sure, thanks Dan!

@nickpan47 I separated the logic for assignment and verification of partition counts as suggested.

One concern I have now, however, is about the utility/usefulness of `IntermediateStreamManager` as an independent class.

1. With my change, `IntermediateStreamManager` cannot operate independently from the `ExecutionPlanner` since it relies on it for traversing the operator graph and grouping conjoined edges.

2. If we have plans to use `IntermediateStreamManager` independently, then our only alternative would be to have it perform the traversal/grouping work currently done in the `ExecutionPlanner` redundantly. In addition to the computational overhead, this would entail promoting the stream grouping class, `StreamSet`, into a package-level class  an option I would not prefer because this class has no way of maintaining its invariant, i.e. the correct categorization of a group of streams, e.g. all vs some vs no partitions set, since `StreamEdge`s are mutable.

3. I also dislike the idea of having `calculatePartitions()` expect both a `JobGraph` _and_ a list of conjoined stream edges since there seems to be quite a bit of overlap between the two. On the other hand, I wouldn't want to reconstruct these groups in the `IntermediateStreamManager` redundantly, unless it could be used independently from the `ExecutionPlanner`.
@vjagadish @weisong44 please take a look
